Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Development of Geolocation Name System (GNS)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project focuses on making geolocations direct, easy to remember, and unambiguous. Disambiguation is a critical part of automation and simplifies infrastructure for the autonomous world. Instead of searching for an address to obtain a geolocation, the goal is to provide a portable, user-friendly, human-readable method. Geolocations are becoming more important in this new mobile world and are already critical for reaching a business, picking up a passenger, delivering a package, or transporting a student. Geolocations will become even more important with the expanding use of autonomous vehicles, robots, and drones. Geolocation information with contextual data can be the foundation for powerful analyses and programmable solutions. Data analytics with these records can provide extraordinary results in scenarios of disease propagation, disaster preparedness, emergency response, population movement, and longitudinal student analysis, which can result in substantial savings on health and disaster recovery and more efficient investment in education.

The goal of this project is to build an open, dynamic, personalizable geolocation repository that serves as the foundation for the next generation of geolocation- enabled applications, including autonomous and Internet-of-Things (IoT)-related solutions, and the output of which can be used in data analytic models for forecasting health, weather, and population growth and/or spread. Geolocation repository and management tools can add interactivity to the information, with capabilities for geolocation updates, near-real-time tracking, and data notifications and the potential to enable the development of programmable solutions. By adding software application programming interfaces above the repository layer with appropriate functions and commands, the geolocation data can power everyday applications to maintain data freshness while being used to advance data analytics. When provided at edge endpoints with strong authorization mechanisms, the information can be bound to Internet domains, emails, or telephones for portability across operating systems, devices, and apps.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) project is to make geolocations direct, easy to remember, and unambiguous. The Geolocation Name System (GNS) was conceptualized in 2018 after the destruction caused by Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico and the slow response to that disaster. During the recovery, the main problem was the lack of accurate geolocation information tied to people and things, which in turn made it difficult to plan and execute emergency response activities. Hundreds of organizations participated in the recovery effort, but as data were not easily shared, some communities received more help than was necessary, while others were forgotten.

In 2020, the effects of COVID-19 forced individuals and businesses to embrace home services. Shelter-at-home orders required businesses to adapt, and geolocation information became vital for companies to successfully fulfill orders for products and services. In the last year alone, an extraordinary number of applications have emerged that ask for geolocation information. This geolocation information is stored in each application's database, resulting in thousands of databases that have duplicate data without clear traceability.

There is also the issue of rural America, which encompasses 60 million people who receive limited services, including access to education, healthcare, and broadband. The GNS can improve those and other services, including offering opportunities for interactivity (e.g., status information from GNS data, which could be used in cases of emergency needs, such as for rescue, medicine, or food) or analysis (e.g., broadband coverage for rural America or disease tracking).

At the same time, the use of geolocations in applications continues to spread and will accelerate further with the expansion of internet of things (IoT) services and autonomous devices. The lack of a standardized protocol for geolocation management means that geolocation data containing personal information reside in thousands, or even hundreds of thousands, of applications, resulting in islands of information without proper accountability or synchronization (for instance, according to Statista, more than six million applications are registered for use with iOS and Android devices). The GNS remedies these deficiencies by offering an open application programming interface (API) that, upon explicit user consent, provides those who have proper authorization with access to a centralized geolocation database.

The goal of this project was to build an open, dynamic, personalizable geolocation repository as a foundation for the next generation of geolocation-enabled applications - including autonomous and IoT-related solutions - and whose output can be used in data analytics, artificial intelligence, and machine-learning models to forecast health variances, weather patterns, and population growth/spread. The project realized a centralized geolocation repository that has dynamic management functionality to add interactivity to the information, including capabilities for geolocation updates, near-real-time tracking, and data notifications, and enables the development of programmable solutions. With software APIs that have appropriate commands and functions above the repository layer, geolocation data powers everyday applications to maintain data freshness while being used to advance data analytics. When provided at edge endpoints that have strong authorization mechanisms, the geolocation information is bound to internet domains, emails, or telephones for portability across operating systems, devices, and apps.
